Morgan Stanley to summarise.

BE11:15am

Q3 organic revenue growth was better than expected, and FY 2019 guidance now looks conservative. Q3 organic ahead, strength across the board: WPP's Q3 organic revenue growth came in at +0.7% (including Kantar), vs MSe -0.6%. After four consecutive quarters of decline, WPP's top line has returned to growth. The performance was driven by North America, which declined by less than expected (-3.5% vs MSe -5%); the UK (+3.1% vs MSe +1.5%); and APAC (+4% vs MSe +1.3%). Europe slightly missed our expectations, growing at +1.7% vs MSe +3%. By function, Global Integrated Agencies returned to growth of +1.7% in Q3, vs -3.4% in Q1 and -0.3% in Q2, with WPP calling out "significant improvement" at Wunderman Thomson, VMLY&R and Grey. Guidance now looks conservative: Guidance for 2019 organic revenue growth has been reiterated at -1.5% to -2%, but this now looks conservative – after nine months, organic revenue growth is -1.1%, which means the implied Q4 growth is now -0.7% to -5%. Given the breadth of the recovery in Q3, we think this looks less plausible and believe consensus will likely move to the top end of the guidance range. On margins, WPP expects headline operating margin less pass-through costs to decline by around 1 percentage point on constant currency.

Soundbuy @A.M - Only 251 non-alcoholic Becks were bought .....so yes is the answer
Pete Oh, OK. I actually travel more outside the EU than within it, so that might be why I thought that?

11:16 am
BE11:17am

WPP reported 3Q19 organic growth of +0.7% (+0.5% excluding Kantar), beating company-compiled consensus -0.6% and our forecasts of -0.2%, mainly driven by North America (-3.2% vs GSe -4.5%) and ROW (+4.1% vs GSe +2.0%), with China in particular seeing a significant improvement. This makes WPP the only agency to have reported a beat on organic growth and a sequential qoq improvement in 3Q so far, notably in the US, compared to an average 90bp miss and 130bp qoq deceleration for Publicis, OMC and IPG. FY guidance of -1.5%-2.0% organic net sales growth was reiterated, although this now also applies to the group ex Kantar, implying a deterioration to -2.5% to -4.3% in 4Q, which we view as too conservative given the recent momentum and the annualisation of certain account losses. We believe these results further demonstrate the progress of WPP’s turnaround plan and should be well taken by the market following recent mixed results from peers.
We raise our FY organic growth marginally to -1.1% from -1.2%, implying -1.5% in 4Q, compared to the consensus range of -1.5% to -1.2% (average -1.4%) for 2019. Our 2019/20E EPS, however, decreases by -0.9%/-3.8% to 99.5p/98.8p due to FX and as a result our 12-month price target decreases by c.3% to 1160p.

Management is not changing full-year guidance of -1.5% to ‑2.0% organic and -100bp operating (“Our growth in Q3 is encouraging but we are focused on delivering these longer-term goals and know there will be twists and turns along the way. Our guidance for 2019 remains unchanged”). The Q4 implied growth however becomes easier (-2.3% to achieve -1.5%; -4.0% to achieve -2.0%). Consensus is already at -1.4% therefore organic upgrades are not necessarily forthcoming but confidence should clearly increase and that matter with agencies.

There is also a significant catalyst remaining, namely how WPP will return the Kantar proceeds to shareholders. We overwhelmingly favour a buyback as opposed to a special dividend with share consolidation. A buyback would create buying pressure but also offer downside protection in case of a recession. Reiterate Overweight with 1,130p target.

BE11:24am

Here's UBS

BE11:25am

A: With 3Q19 trading statement management cut pre-tax profit guidance for 2019 to "10% below 2018 and consensus (£135m)", implying a pre-tax profit of £122m for FY2019 (vs UBS at £134m). This is primarily due to weakness in European SB latex, management expect volumes to fall by 10% y/y. At the end of September net debt to EBITDA was at 1.4x, excluding the proceeds from the recent rights issue. Management target the completion of the Omnova acquisition by late 2019, when we expect net debt to EBITDA to rise to 2.9x (pre guidance cut) by the end of 2020.

Irish HF guy @Alewis2005, agreed. Most Airlines within EU require travel document, but that is different to no border control so no ID required to travel between countries, but Airlines effectively act as a form of control
11:25 am
BE11:25am

What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: In Performance Elastomers (50% of 2019 EBIT) European volumes are expected to down 10% y-o-y reflecting weakness in key end markets, particularly paper (36% of PE sales) resulting in significantly lower unit margins. Pricing in the Asian nitrile latex market has come under pressure due to the ramp up of new capacity (Synthomer ~90kt and Lotte Chemical ~140kt) this has been offset by volume growth resulting in stable unit margins y/y. Weaker volumes in Functional Solutions (39% of EBIT) was offset by an improvement in unit margins resulting in EBIT coming in flat y/y. Industrial Specialities (11% of EBIT) volumes and unit margins were flat vs 9M18.

BE11:26am

Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Management's guidance for 2019 has become more cautious "if the current weakness persists through 4Q, the board expects underlying PTP to be 10% below 2018 and current consensus". This would imply that 2H19 PTP will be down by ~12% y/y and a ~20% to consensus for 2H19. This would also point to a weaker start to 2020 than expected.

BE11:26am

Valuation: How would we expect investors to react?
A: The shares will react negatively to the weaker trading statement and the prospect of significantly higher leverage once the Omnova acquisition is completed. If we assume a 20% cut to Synthomer's 2020 EBIT and add back Omnova's contribution for 2020 net debt to EBITDA would increase by 0.4x to 3.3x.

BE11:28am

Outside SBR, the balance of Synthomer’s business – more than 80% of its volume and 85% of its operating profit – continues to perform well, with the planned expansions in NBR and in functional solutions delivering product to market, and industrial specialties holding margins. Volume is up in all three, reflecting the additional capacity, and in NBR in particular there has been no reduction in margin.

BE11:29am

Despite the downgrade, we continue to see Synthomer as a stock offering relative earnings resilience, exposure to better structured markets than any time in its own recent history, and an increasing emphasis on premium specialty chemicals, added to by the pending Omnova acquisition. Given this, its EV/EBITDA multiple to UK peers – 9.2x 2020E against peers average of 13.3x, a discount of 30% based on consensus numbers and our estimate of today's move in Synthomer consensus – feels wrong to us, and we retain our existing BUY. We are reducing our price target by 5% to 525p (based primarily on 2020E EV/EBIT), reflecting the lower earnings

Zinc and chrome guidance trimmed

VV75 @den, you're reading too many millenial articles
BE11:37am

Copper, coal all below expectations. Let's get HSBC to summarise shall we.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Glencore’s Q3 production was a bit mixed, with copper and
coal largely in line, zinc and ferrochrome missing our estimates and nickel and cobalt coming in stronger. Overall, we see this as a broadly in-line operating result and a non-event for the stock. In terms of guidance, as we had been expecting, the company has trimmed its 2019 production ranges for copper, zinc and ferrochrome but the rest are unchanged. Our 2019 production estimates are now within the new guided ranges, albeit towards the lower ends across all divisions.

den @VV75 - whats a millennial ?????
BE11:39am

Copper and coal segments in line with our estimates: Q3 copper at 353kt and coal at 36mt were largely in line with our estimates. FY19 copper guidance was trimmed by 15kt to 1,385kt (+- 40kt) reflecting the year-to-date performance. This compares to our 1,377kt estimate. Coal guidance was maintained at 145mt (+- 3mt) and compares to our 141mt estimate.
Zinc and ferrochrome missed our estimates: Q3 zinc output was 273kt (-3% vs our estimate) while ferrochrome output of 231kt was significantly below our estimate. Ferrochrome weakness was already flagged by Merafe at the start of this week, and hence was not a big disappointment and reflects longer maintenance in the quarter.
Accordingly, 2019 guidance for both these divisions was lowered. Zinc guidance has been reduced by 85kt to 1,110 (+- 25kt) reflecting a delayed restart of Iscaycruz in Peru, Contonga placed on care and maintenance as well as ground stability issues at Tishinsky in Kazakhstan. Ferrochrome guidance is down 30kt to 1,450kt (+- 25kt) mainly reflecting the maintenance that impacted Q3 and in response to the generally weak current market conditions. Our zinc and ferrochrome production estimates are 1,091kt and 1,430kt, respectively.
Nickel and cobalt comfortably above our estimates: Q3 nickel output of 34kt was 10% above our estimate and cobalt output of 13.1kt was 20% stronger than our estimate. Guidance for both commodities was unchanged at 128kt and 43kt, respectively, and we raise our estimates slightly following the better-than-expected Q3. Gold output was in line with our estimates, while silver and oil production for the quarter was ahead of our estimates. 2019 guidance for oil is unchanged at 5.5mbbl (+/-0.2), compared to our 5.2mbbl estimate.
Target price unchanged at 285p: We have updated our model to reflect the company’s Q3 2019 production report, making small changes to our estimates. We maintain our Buy rating and our 285p target price, based on the rounded average of our DCF and multiples-based valuation.

A long road to rebuilding the trust: Following a disappointing 1H19, which resulted in Glencore’s operating credentials being called into question (largely as a result of the performance of the African Copper business), today’s operations update was always going to be closely watched. With something of a mixed production report, including trims of full-year guidance, we expect that the jury will still be out for many investors as to whether Glencore have indeed begun to ‘turn the corner’ operationally.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Maintain Outperform rating: Glencore has had a very difficult 2019, however on more normalised assumptions (longer term) Glencore does exhibit potential for significant valuation upside (i.e. 2021E FCF yield of ~16% (greater than 2x the peer group average), NPV of £3.60ps (~55% upside), HOLT® implied value of £3.25 (~40% upside)). The key for Glencore to begin to regain the market’s trust (and perhaps realise some of that value upside) is to progressively show strong delivery versus its operational improvement plans.

BE11:54am

Barclays’ Q3 results are 10%/14% ahead of JPMe/company consensus on
adj PBT driven by a good top-line and jaws performance in UK & CIB and
should help drive a recovery in the shares in our view. Group revenue is
3% above consensus, pre-provision profits 8% ahead and clean PBT 14%
ahead with a net loss due to £1.4bn PPI costs. CT1 at 13.4% (JPMe 12.9%)
benefitted from the removal of the Op risk floor which added 60bps while
rebasing the group’s target to around 13.5% (from 13%) and we see DPS
of 9p on track for FY'19. We highlight a decent sequential improvement in
UK revenue driven by Mortgage growth of £2.9bn as well as strong
performance from the CIB where PBT was £115m or 16% ahead of
consensus. Mgmt continue to target greater than 9% and greater than 10% ROTE for 19/20 but note that the rate and macro environment have made it more challenging,
particularly for 2020. We think this is already reflected in consensus
ROTE of 8.3%/8.4% for 19/20E and expect these results to lead to lowsingle-
digit EPS upgrades for consensus driven by topline partly offset by
higher seasonality in US Card provisions. The shares trade at 0.6x
P/TNAV for 2020E RoNAV of 9.1%, we remain OW.

BE11:56am

ndriven by weaker UK economic outlook and lower rates environment.
Capital return: The company believes the new 13.5% CET1 threshold is
nappropriate and that it can increase capital returns when the company reaches above that level. BARC would like to keep its payout ratio at 40% and to see buybacks given where the stock is trading (if and when appropriate), albeit without providing any timeframe for these.
IB: The bank gained market share in prime financing in both FICC and Equities. It
ncontinued to invest in its franchise, rolling out new algorithms for electronic trading products and overall sees its equities franchise as strategic given the need to be represented across all asset classes.
UK growth: The bank continues to be defensively positioned, focusing on
ngrowing loans in secured (mortgages up £2.9bn qoq) as opposed to unsecured lending (card balances shrunk slightly in the quarter).
Impairments: The banks expects impairment levels in the UK to increase again
nin 4Q but to remain somewhat below the prior guidance of £200mn per quarter (as consumer loan balances have reduced).

Sale growth momentum to remain strong; initiate as Buy, PT 330p
We initiate on boohoo group as Buy with a 330p 12m price target (22% upside). We expect: 1) sales growth of c.40% for FY20 (slightly above guidance of 33%-38%), driven by strong growth in PrettyLittleThing (PLT) and an acceleration at boohoo brand; 2) a significant contribution from the US and EU, with sales CAGRs (FY2019-22E) of 39% and 47%, in addition to c.27% growth in the UK; and 3) a broadly stable EBIT margin and strong FCF generation.

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

Competitive-priced own brand; capex light but slightly rising opex
boohoo’s 100% own brand, supply chain proximity and test-repeat model give it flexibility to respond to changes in customer preferences and limit inventory risk. In addition, boohoo offers competitively priced products, and is effective at using social media platforms such as Instagram for marketing; it also has lower capex requirements given significant use of third-party platforms. Sales growth has been strong, but going forward, international growth and improvements in the customer offer (e.g. faster returns/refunds globally) could require higher investments; we expect a marginal decline (rather than a step change) in EBITDA margin to 9.6% by FY21E (9.9% in FY19). We also recognise £550mn of minority interest reflecting the c.34% stake currently not owned in PLT.

Tax Realist Well it was guinness in Dublin...but
BE12:04pm

Valuation and risks
boohoo trades on c.2.3x EV/sales CY20E (ASOS at 0.82x, Zalando 1.28x) with a sales CAGR (2019-22E) of 31% (ASOS +15%, Zalando +17%). Our 330p price target is DCF-driven (9.0% WACC, TG +2%). Risks to our view include a significant downturn in demand (especially in the UK), higher than expected cost to grow and rising competition.
